evidence: autoimmune CD8+ T cells, which are the final mediators of beta cell destruction, circulate at similar frequencies in type 1 diabetic and healthy individuals.
Beta cells fulfil this task by adapting ER function to these changing demands by triggering the unfolded protein response (UPR).
references: Eizirik DL, Miani M, Cardozo AK (2013) Signalling danger: endoplasmic reticulum stress and the unfolded protein response in pancreatic islet inflammation. Diabetologia 56(2):234-241. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00125-012-2762-3

evidence: The UPR decreases the ingress of newly synthesised proteins into the ER and increases the extrusion of misfolded proteins and the synthesis of ER chaperones, thus upgrading the folding capacity of the organelle.
references: Eizirik DL, Miani M, Cardozo AK (2013) Signalling danger: endoplasmic reticulum stress and the unfolded protein response in pancreatic islet inflammation. Diabetologia 56(2):234-241. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00125-012-2762-3

evidence: If this fails to restore ER homeostasis, beta cells eventually activate the apoptotic pathway.
references: Eizirik DL, Miani M, Cardozo AK (2013) Signalling danger: endoplasmic reticulum stress and the unfolded protein response in pancreatic islet inflammation. Diabetologia 56(2):234-241. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00125-012-2762-3

evidence: This dysregulated ER stress also augments local inflammation via activation of the NF-kB pathway, increasing the local release of chemokines that attract immune cells.
references: Eizirik DL, Miani M, Cardozo AK (2013) Signalling danger: endoplasmic reticulum stress and the unfolded protein response in pancreatic islet inflammation. Diabetologia 56(2):234-241. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00125-012-2762-3

evidence: Predisposing HLA Class II alleles account for most of the genetic risk, which points to the role of antigen-presenting cells (APCs) in driving disease progression via the uptake of beta cell material and the priming of CD4+ T cells.

Other type 1 diabetes-associated gene variants can synergise with ER stress to potentiate local inflammation. These include MDA5 (also known as IFIH1), which encodes a cytoplasmic receptor for viral double-stranded RNA.
references: Op de Beeck A, Eizirik DL (2016) Viral infections in type 1 diabetes mellitus - why the beta cells? Nat Rev Endocrinol 12(5):263-273. https://doi.org/10.1038/nrendo.2016.30

evidence: MDA5 (also known as IFIH1), which encodes a cytoplasmic receptor for viral double-stranded RNA and is upregulated in human islets upon Coxsackievirus B (CVB) infection and potentiates chemokine release.
references: Op de Beeck A, Eizirik DL (2016) Viral infections in type 1 diabetes mellitus - why the beta cells? Nat Rev Endocrinol 12(5):263-273. https://doi.org/10.1038/nrendo.2016.30
